newsitem.title: GERMANY: German secondary aluminium output seen up in 1996.
newsitem.headline: German secondary aluminium output seen up in 1996.

text.p: Secondary aluminium output by Germany's leading producers is expected to rise to 350,000 tonnes in 1996, up two percent from 1995, a statement from industry association VDS said on Tuesday.
The figure applied to 11 VDS member companies, which together accounted for 80 percent of German output.
VDS chairman Erich Oetinger said the trend in output contrasted with unsatisfactory profitability, although this might improve in line with a general economic upswing next year.
Aluminium's recent uptrend on the London Metals Exchange (LME) was also encouraging.
Oetinger said VDS margins were being squeezed as sales prices of casting alloys fell faster than buying-in prices of scrap, which accounted for 75 percent of product prices.
The gap was created by import pressure from alloy ingots and the fact that an estimated 160,000 tonnes of scrap would be exported this year rather than processed at home.
High environmental standards had resulted in inflated processing and production costs which discouraged the use of domestic aluminium scrap.
Oetinger said low prices on the LME alloy contract threatened the viability of German operations.
Low-cost producers had used the contract to sell surplus material rather than produce in line with demand trends, he said.
As a result, LME stocks had risen and prices had been eroded while raw materials were tied up in warehouses.
EU anti-dumping duties on Brazilian and Chinese silicon imports were also affecting producer prices.
